title: RS20985
content: Federal agencies use procurement contracts for various tasks, including forest stewardship services. These contracts outline tasks such as cutting unmerchantable trees or underbrush and specifying how the materials should be treated. Agencies currently award contracts to the lowest bidder, but Congress could consider other factors for selection. It is possible to specify the desired resulting condition of the area to be treated in procurement contracts for stewardship services. Congress could consider factors other than the lowest bidder, such as local employment or quality of past performance. Some suggest collecting commercially valuable material under a contract and selling it separately, a practice known as log sales, common in Europe. Some suggest collecting commercially valuable material under a procurement contract and selling it separately, a practice known as log sales, common in Europe. The Forest Service has the authority for log sales but has not extensively used it. The traditional procurement contracting method is favored for its simplicity and familiarity to agency personnel. Advantages of Traditional Procurement Contracting for forest stewardship include simplicity, familiarity to agency personnel, and the opportunity for congressional control and oversight. Numerous private contractors are available to bid on contract proposals. The current contracting system allows for congressional control and oversight of federal forest stewardship. Annual budget justifications could help Congress assess agency efforts and target appropriations to areas of greatest need. Traditional service contracting for federal forest stewardship has limitations due to potential high federal expenditures. The Forest Service has identified millions of federal acres in need of stewardship. The Forest Service has identified 36 million federal acres at high risk of ecological damage from wildfires, with treatment costs potentially exceeding $20 billion. Treating 75 million acres of biomass could cost over $20 billion, with potential total costs for all 231 million federal acres around $70 billion. Modifications to traditional service procurement contracting could hinder efforts to improve federal forest health. The total cost for treating all 231 million federal acres could be around $70 billion. Proposed changes to traditional service procurement contracting for forest stewardship may impede efforts to enhance federal forest health. Using desired conditions instead of tasks for forest stewardship could be more effective, but standardized measures for this approach have not been developed yet. Proposed changes to traditional service procurement contracting for forest stewardship may face challenges due to the lack of standardized measures for desired forest conditions. Advocates suggest separate log sales for commercially valuable wood, but issues such as log cutting, contractor independence, and agency inexperience with log sales pose limitations. Traditional service procurement contracting may not be the most effective method for improving federal forest health. To improve federal forest health, combining activities like salvage sales with mixed-species planting or prescribed burning after thinning is necessary. Some propose a new approach to contracting for forest stewardship by trading commercially valuable timber for services in the same area, known as land management. Some propose a new approach to contracting for forest stewardship by trading commercially valuable timber for services in the same area, known as land management service contracts. These contracts require timber purchasers to perform other related services, such as precommercial thinning or watershed restoration, in exchange for paying less for the harvested timber. Federal laws prohibit agencies from retaining and using the receipts from selling assets. In 1998, Congress established a broader test of goods-for-services contracting, allowing for stewardship end result contracting demonstration. In 1998, Congress established a broader test of goods-for-services contracting for stewardship end result projects. Subsequent appropriations acts authorized multiple stewardship contracting demonstration projects. In 2002, the House and Senate versions of H.R. 2646 differed on authorizing goods-for-services contracting for the Forest Service, with the House version allowing unlimited contracts through FY2007 and the Senate version authorizing 28 contracts through FY2006, with specific requirements for traditional service contracts and reports comparing approaches. The Senate-passed version of the bill did not include provisions for goods-for-services contracting, despite President Bush's proposal to use this method for reducing forest fuels. The debate over stewardship contracting continued in the FY2003 Interior Appropriations Act. Bush proposed goods-for-services stewardship contracting to reduce forest fuels in his Healthy Forests Initiative. The Senate debated this as part of wildfire management funding in the FY2003 Interior Appropriations Act. The debate on the Healthy Forests Initiative provisions delayed action on the bill, and finally, the FY2003 Interior appropriations were enacted as Division F of P.L.108-7. Section 323 of the FY1999 Interior Appropriations Act was amended by P.L.108-7 to authorize stewardship end result contracting through FY2013, extending the program to BLM lands and national forests, removing constraints on selecting a contracting officer, and modifying cutting objectives. The FY1999 Interior Appropriations Act was amended to authorize stewardship end result contracting through FY2013, allowing the removal of "noncommercial" from cutting objectives and selecting a contracting officer without constraints. The statute enables agencies to impose non-timber harvesting requirements on purchasers, offsetting the cost of services with the value of timber or forest products removed. It remains unclear if stewardship contracts can be used in certain areas. The statute authorizes removing vegetation and using the value of timber or forest products to offset service costs. Goods-for-services contracting can lead to greater efficiency and lower costs in forest stewardship activities by utilizing the same equipment and personnel for both tasks. Goods-for-services contracting in forest stewardship activities can lead to greater efficiency and lower costs by utilizing the same equipment and personnel for multiple tasks. This approach combines the sale of goods with the performance of services, potentially reducing total costs and offering off-budget financing benefits. Goods-for-services contracting in forest stewardship activities can lead to greater efficiency and lower costs by combining the sale of goods with the performance of services. This approach offers off-budget financing benefits and allows federal agencies to buy stewardship services with timber assets instead of appropriations. Contracting is one proposed approach where federal agencies can buy stewardship services with timber assets instead of appropriations. However, using goods-for-services contracts may lead to higher contracting costs due to combining multiple activities in one contract. The Forest Service's procedures for pilot tests of goods-for-services contracting were noted to be complex and cumbersome. The Forest Service's procedures for pilot tests of goods-for-services contracting were criticized for being a complicated combination of traditional service and timber sale contracting, resulting in higher costs and requiring more upfront effort. Simplifying contracting procedures and providing longer-term authorization were suggested to realize the benefits of goods-for-services contracting. The provision for goods-for-services contracting provides longer-term authorization, but may lack congressional oversight. Other federal financing mechanisms have also faced minimal oversight. This could allow agencies to use goods-for-services contracting with little public participation. Goods-for-services contracting, such as the Forest Service's KV Fund, has minimal congressional oversight, allowing agencies to use it for years without public participation. Critics question the appropriateness of this type of contracting, as it creates incentives for managers to increase timber sales to provide services. Exchanging goods for services creates incentives for managers to increase timber sales to provide services, leading to "perverse incentives" where environmentally damaging activities are supported to generate funds for environmental restoration. This exchange may create similar incentives for forest stewardship activities. Exchanging timber for forest stewardship activities may create incentives for wildfire protection by cutting and removing non-commercial woody biomass. This approach emphasizes stewardship on lands with commercial timber, potentially limiting opportunities for environmentally damaging activities to generate funds for environmental restoration. The use of goods-for-services contracts for forest stewardship activities may limit opportunities for stewardship on federal forests that need treatment. Some question the appropriateness of a broad-scale, long-term program, noting the difficulty in evaluating the success of such contracts. The effectiveness and efficiency of goods-for-services stewardship contracting have not been independently audited despite being seen as an important experimental opportunity to test alternative contracting arrangements under real-world conditions.
